title.text: Developing further speech recognition resources for Welsh

abstractContent.text: This paper reports on ongoing research into developing large-vocabulary continuous speech recognition (LVCSR) for the Welsh language.
We address data design issues and the method for data collection using a purposely designed application for mobile devices.

We also discuss the application of the data including the design and collection of a small speech corpus to cover the commands used to control a robotic arm in Welsh on a Raspberry Pi computer the licensing of the project and our hopes for the application of the project resources to other languages .

introductionContent.text: This paper presents an overview of the GALLU (Gwaith Adnabod Lleferydd Uwch-IPA:, translation: further speech recognition work) project to develop speech recognition technology for the Welsh language.
Wales has a population of around 3 million people, of whom around 20% speak Welsh (Office for National.
Lesser-resourced languages typically lag in digital innovation, including in language technologies.
However since 2012, the Welsh Government has updated and revised a strategy for supporting Welsh-language technology.

Emphasis is placed on "more tools and resources … to facilitate the use of Welsh, including in the digital environment" and "the development of new Welsh-language software applications and digital services".
With funding from the Welsh Government and S4C (the Welsh language television channel), the GALLU project aims to develop speech recognition technology for the Welsh language.

The resources will be available under a permissive open-source licence, and will therefore be available for use in abroad spectrum of platforms and devices, including voice control for smart televisions.
